items.title: Trump could leave trade deal next year, top trade official says
As cleanup costs mount, oilpatch may be forced to pay deposit before drilling new wells
items.summary_auto: Alberta’s premier is floating the idea of making oil and gas companies pay a deposit before they can drill a new well, as the provincial government tries to tackle the large number of old oil and gas wells which require cleanup.

items.title: Putin says Russia will take Donbas by force if it's not ceded by Ukraine
items.summary_auto: President Vladimir Putin said in an interview published on Thursday that Russia would take full control of Ukraine's Donbas region by force unless Ukrainian forces withdraw — something Kyiv has flatly rejected.

items.title: Retiree warns others after losing $3K to crypto fraud using AI video of prime minister
Steve Cropper, legendary soul music songwriter and guitarist, dead at 84
items.summary_auto: Steve Cropper, the lean, soulful guitarist and songwriter who helped anchor the celebrated Memphis backing band Booker T. and the M.G. 's at Stax Records and co-wrote the classics Green Onions, (Sittin' on) the Dock of the Bay and In the Midnight Hour, has died. He was 84.

items.title: Chain restaurants are out. Restaurant groups are in
items.summary_auto: A peek behind the curtain at how big players in the restaurant industry, who own multiple, seemingly independent restaurants, leverage better buying power as a way to survive post-COVID.

items.title: Reservation system coming to Skyline Trail in Cape Breton Highlands
items.summary_auto: The system for “parking and timed access” will be launched in late June.

items.title: Tow truck operators urge drivers to slow down after fatal hit-and-run on 401
items.summary_auto: Southwestern Ontario’s towing industry is feeling a mixture of disappointment and heartbreak following the hit-and-run death of one of their own this week, with some saying the death is proof that the attitudes of drivers need to change for safety to be possible.

items.title: Equipment failure thwarts N.B. power plant from resuming production
items.summary_auto: As frigid temperatures approach New Brunswick, the troubled Point Lepreau nuclear generating station missed its expected return to service date earlier this week.

items.title: Israel identifies body of returned hostage as Thai national
items.summary_auto: Israel has identified the remains of the hostage it received from Hamas on Wednesday as Thai agricultural worker Sudthisak Rinthalak, the prime minister's office said on Thursday.

items.title: Transforming F1: How the female and Gen Z fandom is shaping the sport’s future
items.summary_auto: In Canada and the U.S., F1 has gone from niche motorsport to mainstream obsession in just a few years. It’s a shift driven by a new wave of fans who are remaking the sport's social media landscape and driving the call for representation.

items.title: Your favourite TV shows are changing how episodes are released. Is appointment viewing back?
items.summary_auto: From hit dramas like Stranger Things and The Summer I Turned Pretty, to attention grabbing reality shows, many shows on streaming platforms that made their name on binge watching are now releasing episodes weekly or in bite-sized chunks. Experts say the format and social factors are driving some fans to catch episodes when they air, though with more flexibility than broadcast TV allows.

items.title: A month before a boy in her care died, Ontario woman said she worried he'd die, trial hears
items.summary_auto: The first-degree murder trial of Brandy Cooney and Becky Hamber in Milton, Ont., heard texts in which the women questioned whether a boy in their care might be dying, a month before he did in December 2022.

items.title: How singing in a choir might help people find their voices after a stroke
items.summary_auto: A randomized controlled trial involving 12 weekly choir sessions for participants who have developed aphasia from strokes, aims to find out if singing together helps them re-gain their ability to speak and write.

items.title: Australia's youth social media ban is looming. Could Canada roll out something similar?
items.summary_auto: As platforms like Instagram, TikTok, Snapchat and YouTube begin to comply with Australia's new landmark law banning social media for those under 16, Aussie youth are likely starting to see pop-ups about their accounts being deactivated or put on hold. Is there a potential for ripple effects in Canada?

items.title: Food prices could increase in 2026, with meat leading the way, say Dalhousie researchers
items.summary_auto: Food prices in Canada could increase by four to six per cent next year, largely led by pricier meat products, according to a forecast by researchers at Dalhousie University.

items.title: Trade tensions temporarily on backburner as PM visits Washington for FIFA celebration
items.summary_auto: Though Prime Minister Mark Carney’s upcoming trip to the U.S. is all about FIFA soccer, it’s hard to overlook the political tensions ahead of the upcoming review of the Canada-U.S.-Mexico Agreement. If there’s an opportunity to nudge Canada-U.S. relations in a more positive direction, insiders suggest Carney should take it.

items.title: Trump offered Putin a tactical victory in Ukraine. It wasn’t enough
items.summary_auto: The Kremlin has again rejected U.S. President Donald Trump's latest proposals to end the war in Ukraine. While Trump has tried to entice Russian President Vladimir Putin with offers of Ukrainian territory and lucrative future commercial contracts, Putin's goal of subjugating Ukraine isn't something Trump can put on the table.

items.title: Actual leader of the B.C. Conservatives up in the air — and so are their next moves
Munk debate featuring former Israeli officials met with protests, allegations of war crimes
items.summary_auto: As many as 200 people protested outside the Munk Debates in Toronto on Wednesday, where a panel of all-Israeli speakers discussed whether a two-state solution is in the best interest of Israel.

items.title: Tiny gap, big problem: Toronto’s 6-day apartment fire explained
items.summary_auto: A fire has been burning inside the walls of a Toronto apartment complex for six days. For The National, CBC’s Ashley Fraser breaks down the unique characteristics of the Thorncliffe Park buildings that are making the fire so challenging to put out.

items.title: Mastermind behind 2021 kidnapping of missionaires in Haiti — including a Canadian — sentenced to life
items.summary_auto: The former head of the notorious Haitian gang 400 Mawozo was sentenced on Wednesday in a U.S. court to life in prison for masterminding the 2021 kidnapping of a group of American missionaries, along with one Canadian.

items.title: Man who killed attacker in Banff used 'excessive' force, sentenced to 2-year house arrest
items.summary_auto: After learning the man who killed their loved one would not go to jail, several of Ryden Brogden’s family members stormed out of the courtroom. On Wednesday, a judge announced John Sproule would serve a conditional sentence order involving two years of house arrest.

items.title: Marathon meetings next week will decide bulk of Canadian men's Olympic hockey team
items.summary_auto: The Canadian management group will meet from Sunday through Tuesday, and expect to have 70 to 80 per cent of the roster written in pen by the end. The players selected will be competing on a smaller than expected ice surface in Milan, where the Santagiulia Ice Hockey Arena is under a tight timeline for completion.

items.title: U.S. producers warn Trump’s tariffs jeopardize their access to Canada, Mexico
items.summary_auto: A crucial hearing in Washington into the future of Canada’s three-way trade deal with the U.S. and Mexico kicked off Wednesday with U.S. agriculture, business and policy groups urging the Trump administration not to scrap the agreement.

items.title: Prime Minister Carney hosts Canadian tennis star Mboko on Parliament Hill
items.summary_auto: Prime Minister Mark Carney welcomed Canadian tennis star Victoria Mboko to Parliament Hill on Wednesday, telling the Toronto teen that Canadians are proud of her breakthrough season on the WTA Tour.

items.title: Judges' association taking federal government to court over rejection of $28K raise
items.summary_auto: A group representing federally appointed judges is taking the government to court over its decision to reject a recommended pay raise of at least $28,000.

items.title: New research suggests surge in incurable prostate cancer from lack of early screening
items.summary_auto: Canadian research suggests recommendations against screening for prostate cancer has led to a rise in the rates of stage 4 cases and less progress in mortality, even as other experts disagree and cite harms of overdiagnosis and overtreatment.

items.title: Doctor who sold Matthew Perry ketamine sentenced to 2-1/2 years in prison
items.summary_auto: California doctor Salvador Plasencia was sentenced to two and a half years in prison on Wednesday after he pleaded guilty to illegally supplying Friends star Matthew Perry with ketamine. The powerful sedative caused the actor's overdose death in 2023.

items.title: Cuba reconnects power grid after partial failure left Havana, much of west in dark
items.summary_auto: Cuba said it had reconnected its electrical grid and was gradually restoring power after a partial collapse on Wednesday left the capital Havana and much of western Cuba in the dark, the latest incident in an energy crisis that has left millions suffering from prolonged blackouts for months.

items.title: Nor'easter slams Canada's East Coast
items.summary_auto: A nor’easter pummeled Atlantic Canada on Wednesday, bringing snow, rain and strong winds to the region.

items.title: What to know about the imported pistachios linked to lasting salmonella outbreak
items.summary_auto: Iranian pistachios previously imported to Canada need to be held and tested for salmonella before being sold, federal officials say.

items.title: John Rustad removed as leader of B.C. Conservative Party, but he says he's not leaving
Ont. councillor charged after allegedly threatening potential mayoral candidate
items.summary_auto: A municipal councillor from Clarington, Ont. is facing criminal charges over alleged threats made in a voicemail involving a potential mayoral candidate, police say. Coun. Corinna Traill has denied making any threats, saying the voicemail in question was generated by artificial intelligence.

items.title: Calgary teen accused of using AI to sexualize photos of high school girls
items.summary_auto: A Calgary teen has been charged with several criminal offences after he allegedly used AI technology to sexualize photos of teen girls at several local high schools.

items.title: Delayed introduction of First Nations clean water bill 'unacceptable,' say chiefs
items.summary_auto: Chiefs in Ontario are denouncing the federal government’s delayed introduction of a bill to ensure First Nations have safe drinking water. They're also concerned that Canada intends to weaken proposed legislation before tabling it.
